item.title: The Age of Disclosure
item.description:
The Age of Disclosure ðŸ”—

A 2025 American documentary film directed and produced by Dan Farah, exploring the alleged existence and cover-up of extraterrestrial intelligence.

Release ðŸ”—

The film premiered at SXSW (South by Southwest Film & TV Festival) on March 9, 2025. This section highlights the film’s debut at a major film festival.

Reception ðŸ”—

The film received “mixed or average” reviews, earning a score of 52 out of 100 on Metacritic based on four critics. Owen Gleiberman of Variety questioned the film’s evidence, expressing skepticism about the quality and authenticity of the presented footage.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including articles from Hollywood Reporter, People, The Guardian, the SXSW 2025 schedule, and Metacritic. These references provide verification for the information presented about the film’s production, release, and reception.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to the film’s official website and its IMDb page. These links offer additional resources for those interested in learning more about the film.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Age_of_Disclosure

item.title: List of films featuring extraterrestrials
item.description:
List of Films Featuring Extraterrestrials ðŸ”—

This Wikipedia page serves as a comprehensive index of films that prominently feature extraterrestrial beings. It provides a tabular listing of movies, their release years, and any associated franchises.

Film Listing ðŸ”—

The core of the page is a sortable table presenting an extensive list of films featuring extraterrestrials. Each entry includes:

  • Title: The name of the film, linked to its respective Wikipedia page for more information.
  • Year: The year the film was released.
  • Franchise: If the film is part of a larger franchise, it’s indicated here, linking to the franchise’s Wikipedia page. Many films are standalone entries, while others belong to well-known series like Alien, Cloverfield, Star Wars, Star Trek, Marvel Cinematic Universe, and Godzilla.

The list spans a wide range of cinematic history, from early silent films to recent releases, and encompasses various genres, including science fiction, horror, comedy, and animation.

See Also ðŸ”—

This section provides links to other relevant Wikipedia articles, including:

  • Lists of fictional extraterrestrials
  • UFOs in fiction

These links allow readers to explore related topics and delve deeper into the portrayal of aliens and UFOs in various forms of media.

References ðŸ”—

This section contains a comprehensive list of citations used to verify the information presented in the film listing. These references include links to reputable sources such as:

  • AllMovie
  • Rotten Tomatoes
  • The Hollywood Reporter
  • Empire Magazine
  • IGN
  • The New York Times
  • Variety
  • Space.com
  • British Film Institute
  • Turner Classic Movies
  • And many more.

These references ensure the accuracy and reliability of the information provided on the page.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_films_featuring_extraterrestrials

item.title: Extraterrestrial Civilizations (Book)
item.description:
Extraterrestrial Civilizations (Book) ðŸ”—

This entry details Isaac Asimov’s 1979 book, Extraterrestrial Civilizations, which explores the probability of intelligent extraterrestrial life within the Milky Way galaxy. The book approaches this estimation by systematically analyzing the requirements for life to exist.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the core argument of Asimov’s book. A key concept is the “Earth-like world,” which assumes that habitable planets share similarities with Earth, such as suitable temperature ranges and sufficient gravity for an atmosphere. Asimov starts with an estimated 300 billion stars in the Milky Way. He then progressively reduces this number by considering factors like the presence of planetary systems. The analysis leads to an estimate of roughly 530,000 planets in our galaxy that could potentially harbor technological civilizations.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to the Drake equation, a probabilistic argument used to estimate the number of active, communicative extraterrestrial civilizations in the Milky Way galaxy.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article. These include a review of Extraterrestrial Civilizations by J.H. Jenkins, archived on a personal website, and a listing for the book on The Internet Book Database of Fiction.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrial_Civilizations
